qas.question: What is a kettle called that is used to boil sweet wort after sparging?
How long is sweet wort boiled for after sparging?
What does boiling sweet wort destroy?
What affect do hops have in brewing when they brew for a long time?
Where is the sparge collected from wort put into?
When does water in the sugar evaporate?
During what process is the remaining sugar destroyed?
During what stage can starch sources be added at more than one point?
What increases the longer the starches are boiled?

context: The sweet wort collected from sparging is put into <b4_0>a kettle, or "<a0_0>copper<a0_0/>"<b4_0/> (so called because these vessels were traditionally made from copper), and boiled, usually for <a1_0>about one hour<a1_0/>. <b5_0>During boiling<b5_0/>, water in the wort evaporates, but the sugars and other components of the wort remain; this allows more efficient use of the starch sources in the beer. <b6_0>Boiling<b6_0/> also destroys any remaining <a2_0>enzymes<a2_0/> left over from the mashing stage. Hops are added during boiling as a source of bitterness, flavour and aroma. Hops may be added at more than one point during <b7_0>the boil<b7_0/>. The longer the hops are boiled, the more <a3_0><b8_0>bitterness<b8_0/><a3_0/> they contribute, but the less hop flavour and aroma remains in the beer.
